results.title: The Cleo Laine collection
results.creator_credit: de Montignie Productions, Bill Ramsey and Graeme Rowland
results.brief_description: Recorded live at the Melbourne Concert Hall in 1986, this video presents the sensuous and sultry jazz and blues singer Cleo Laine performing with her husband John Dankworth and the Dankworth Quartet. British born Cleo Laine began her musical career in the early 1950s where she met and married renowned musician John Dankworth in 1958. Together they have toured the world (and still currently touring) but Cleo has also tried her hand at acting on the stage in such plays as “Flesh to a tiger”, “A Midsummer night’s dream” and the title role in Ibsen’s “Hedda Gabler” among many other performances. Songs from this Melbourne concert by this great lady include “Free and easy”, “I love you just the way you are”, “Crazy rhythm”, “Send in the clowns”, “He was beautiful”.

results.creator_credit: Comedia, Stephen Mepham and Robert Grant
results.brief_description: A Los Trios Ringbarkus skit that sees the duo create havoc whilst cleaning a high-rise office block.

results.title: The Cleaners
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Wallhead Film Productions, State Film Centre of Victoria and Malcolm Wallhead
results.brief_description: Opening with views of the city of Melbourne in the early morning, we see the crowds of workers arriving by train and tram. During the day the streets are crowded with people who dispose of rubbish without thought, necessitating an army of cleaners to keep the city clean. Day and night the cleaning goes on, in the early morning the main body of cleaners take over making the city ready for the day to come.

results.title: The Clay circus
results.creator_credit: Texture Films and Herman J. Engel
results.brief_description: Captures, without narration, the spirit of the circus. A clay sculpture, by Shay Rieger, inspired by the color, forms, and motions of the circus, are intercut with segments of actual circus acts.

results.title: The Classroom
results.creator_credit: Eltham Films, Patrick Ryan and Tim Burstall
results.brief_description: Puppet film for children. Sebastian the Fox appears in a typical classroom with children playing pranks on their master as well as on each other. As so often happens the innocent are punished, in this case Sebastian. The offenders are eventually caught and receive their just desserts.

results.title: The Classical idea
results.creator_credit: Educational Broadcasting Corporation and Bayley Silleck
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art of the western world”.
An episode in the comprehensive art history series, “Art of the Western World”, that focuses on the art of the Western classical world. Narrated by Michael Wood, this program focuses on the origins of humanism and classical works of ancient Greece as well as Roman architecture and engineering. Through a discussion of the works in their historical, religious, intellectual and social context, this program provides both a thorough outline of these periods in art history and underlines their relevance to issues outside the parameters of the works themselves.

results.title: The Class of '01: the college of tomorrow
results.creator_credit: Columbia Broadcasting System, Isaac Kleinerman and Peter Poor
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
A glimpse of what the universities of the future (2001) will be like. Examines new multi-media methods such as computerised control centres and closed circuit TV. Community colleges and the possible “bottling in film” of great professors are explained. Advanced methods of teacher training and new educational technologies are shown, and the question of what will happen to the creative processes in tomorrow’s classrooms is explored. Reporter: Walter Cronkite.

results.title: The Class
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Huw Wheldon and John Schlesinger
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “BBC Monitor”.
A close-up of the work of a class in a drama school and of the methods used to train the aspiring actors and actresses. John Schlesinger’s command of the particular directing technique required is such that the film appears to have been made spontaneously during the forty minutes or so of the single class. In fact it needed a week’s shooting and a considerable amount of preparation in order to give this impression. The tutor (Harold Lang) uses the Mercy Speech from ‘The Merchant of Venice’ as a starting point in an improvisation by the students. Originally made for the BBC Television program ‘Monitor’, it is exciting to watch a production in the hands of a dedicated artist.

results.title: The Clarinet. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: World Mirror-Realist Films, EFVA, Ken Cameron and Muir Mathieson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Jack Brymer of the BBC Symphony Orchestra talks about the history of the clarinet. He demonstrates all the instruments which form the clarinet family, from the high E flat to the contra bass, showing how they work and how to play them. Director Muir Mathieson was music director/composer for Sir Alexander Korda’s London films in the 1930s and 1940s.
results.creator_credit_for_label: World Mirror-Realist Films, EFVA, Ken Cameron and Muir Mathieson
